title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz.

The UK is “cautiously optimistic” that the G7 group of advanced nations can agree the broad outlines of a global deal on taxing multinationals following intense discussions in recent days, according to people with knowledge of the talks.

G7 finance ministers will meet in London on Friday and Saturday and are poised to announce that they have agreed the principles for a new system of international corporate taxation, the people told the Financial Times.

Speaking on Thursday evening, UK chancellor Rishi Sunak, who will host the discussions, said: “I'm hugely optimistic that we will deliver some concrete outcomes this weekend.”

On Friday morning the finance ministers of Germany, France, Italy and Spain released a joint statement in which they said there was an “urgent” need to reach an agreement.

Coronavirus digest

  • Anthony Fauci, US chief medical adviser, has called on China to release the medical records of nine people whose illnesses might provide vital clues as to whether the virus first emerged as a result of a lab leak.

  • Japan has delivered 1.2m vaccine jabs to Taiwan, offering relief from a vaccine shortage Taipei has partly blamed on Chinese obstruction.

  • Big Japanese sponsors of the Tokyo Olympics are calling for the Games to be delayed so more spectators can attend as businesses fret over the value of their marketing campaigns. 

  • For Germany's far-right, the lockdown has been a “test run” for dictatorship.

  • The US will donate millions of excess vaccine doses to countries around the world. Japan leads in pledges to Covax, a total of $2.4bn to close the funding gap. (FT, Bloomberg)

Sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter and get the latest updates on our live blog.

In the news

UK and EU launch antitrust probes into Facebook Regulators in Brussels and the UK have launched formal competition investigations into Facebook, in a joint assault on the social media company's use of customer data to dominate in core markets such as digital advertising.

US investors to be barred from 59 Chinese companies The Biden administration is prohibiting Americans from investing in dozens of Chinese defence and surveillance technology companies — such as Huawei and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation — in an effort to stop US capital being used to undermine national security.

Biden open to dropping corporation tax rise in infrastructure talks Joe Biden is prepared to drop his demands for an increase in the US corporation tax rate if enough Republicans agree to support a surge in infrastructure spending, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

Bill Ackman's Spac close to buying 10% stake in Universal Music The hedge fund billionaire is nearing a deal that would lead to Pershing Square Tontine Holdings, his blank-cheque company, acquiring a 10 per cent stake in the record label behind artists such as Lady Gaga and Cyndi Lauper, said people briefed on the matter.

AstraZeneca and Merck's early-stage breast cancer progress Data showed the companies' drug Lynparza significantly reduces recurrence rates for patients with the BRCA genetic mutation. Separately, Cambridge researchers have re-engineered the genetic code of microbes to create a synthetic cell with capabilities unlike anything in nature.

New York to London in 3.5 hours United Airlines has ordered 15 aircraft capable of flying faster than the speed of sound from Denver-based start-up Boom Supersonic, with the aim of carrying passengers as early as 2029. That could allow the aircraft to cut some flight times in half, making trips between San Francisco and Tokyo in six hours.

The days ahead

US jobs data US job creation is expected to have accelerated sharply last month. The government releases May's non-farm payrolls data later and the unemployment rate. A median forecast of economists surveyed points to an increase in employment of 650,000.

Tiananmen Square massacre anniversary Authorities have banned the annual candlelight vigil in Hong Kong to remember those who died in Beijing on June 4 1989. A barrister involved in organising the now-cancelled vigil was arrested on Friday.

Citizens in Peru and Mexico are voting this weekend Peru prepares to choose its fifth president in five years on Sunday in a run-off between Pedro Castillo, a teacher and union activist with no experience of elected office, and Keiko Fujimori, the unpopular daughter of a jailed former authoritarian president. Mexico is also holding crucial elections.

What else we're reading

How a virus can disrupt inflation statistics Surges in price growth in many big economies are worrying investors and central bankers. But part of that trend can be blamed on Covid-19 — with important consequences for how we interpret official data. Economics editor Chris Giles, who led this week's series on inflation, told today's FT News Briefing podcast that “for the first time in about 30 years [inflation] is something we have to think about”.

  • Global food prices have surged by the largest margin in a decade, heightening fears that the inflation initially stoked by pandemic disruption was accelerating.

Las Vegas betting on conferences to inspire revival Trade shows are back and potentially could be the saviour of Las Vegas. Last year, as coronavirus shut casinos and exhibition halls, the total number of visitors to the city plunged 55 per cent. The World of Concrete event will mark the return of conventions to a city whose economy depends on them.

Some gripes about groupthink Groupthink has a terrible reputation, not helped by its Orwellian ring; the term is used so often that Tim Harford begins to fear that we have groupthink about groupthink. There is no shortage of solutions to the problem: the first and simplest is to embrace decision-making processes that require disagreement.

Naomi Osaka's unexpected strength Osaka's decision to shun the press at the French Open tennis — and the tournament itself — seems to be a sign of greater strength than weakness, writes Jo Ellison. As someone who has described herself as cripplingly shy in past interviews, she has realised that in stepping away she is taking back her power.

AI's debate over profits and ethics Public attention has rightly focused on the worrisome uses of artificial intelligence, such as killer robots or facial recognition technology. But what remains unknowable are the benefits that may be lost by not fully using AI in responsible ways, writes John Thornhill.

Podcast of the day

Belarus: More than a moral dilemma Belarus's decision to divert a plane to Minsk to arrest a dissident journalist has renewed international condemnation and calls for sanctions against President Alexander Lukashenko's regime. In this episode of Rachman Review, Gideon talks to Katia Glod, a Belarusian political consultant, about what happens next.
